Award.AwardTitle: Comparative-, Functional-, and Epi-Genomics of Legumes and Nodule Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Scott A. Jackson (University of Georgia)

CoPIs: Robert J. Schmitz (University of Georgia) and Marc Libault (University of Oklahoma-Norman)

Legumes are a group of plants that interact with soil-borne microorganisms to fix atmospheric nitrogen for plant use, an integral part of sustainable agriculture. Although this is a fundamental process, there are many components that are poorly understood and for which a better understanding may lead to plants that more efficiently fix nitrogen. In this project, epigenetic factors, e.g. non-Mendelian, will be examined to determine how these factors respond to interaction with soil microbes and during maturation of the nitrogen fixing organs in the plant. Data generated will include transcriptomes during and after microbe infection as well as epigenomes including DNA methylation and DNA histone modifications that may be induced or responsive to infection.

In addition to a more fundamental understanding of the process of developing organs for nitrogen fixation in legumes, undergraduate students from colleges in New Mexico will be included in summer research internships and collaborative research during the academic year. Outreach seminars will be held in New Mexico to help develop genomics and bioinformatics opportunities for teachers and students to integrate these tools into curriculum and to expose them to the opportunities in this growing field. All sequence data will be deposited at the NCBI Short Read Archive (SRA) with associated metadata deposited at the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO). In addition, all epigenetic data generated in this project will be available through appropriate genome databases including Phytozome, SoyBase and Medicago.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported research on understanding the role of gene regulation in three important crop legume species (soybean, common bean and Medicago truncatula). These plants possess important symbiotic relationships with microorganisms that fix atmospheric nitrogen for plant use. This research was primarily led by undergraduate/graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. We studied how genes are controlled generally in these species by examining gene expression throughout a diverse population of genetically diverse individuals within each species. We focused a significant amount of time investigating the role of DNA methylation, a covalent modification to DNA, in the regulation of how genes are turned “on” and “off”. We discovered that although there is extensive variation in the abundance and location of DNA methylation throughout the genomes of these diverse legume species, that much of the variation is not linked to changes in gene expression. Instead, it seems this particular modified DNA base is mostly localized to ensuring non-gene regions of the genome such as transposons and repeats are maintained in an “off” state, as to not interfere with the normal progression of development and responses to the environment. The major discoveries from this award revealed extensive epigenetic variation within each of these species, especially within soybean, some of which is likely due to domestication. As part of this award, we further developed methods for the study of single cells, as most data produced up until this point have been from mixing diverse cell types from complex plant organs. A major technological breakthrough has occurred since the initiation of this award that enables the use of microfluidic devices to isolate and study populations of single cells. The goal moving forward is to use these technologies to study how the cells that are co-inhabited by microorganisms respond to the microorganisms to fix atmospheric nitrogen.

In collaboration with Mr. Michael Gonzales we hosted numerous workshops for undergraduate students from throughout the state of New Mexico to provide experiential learning opportunities in both laboratory experiments and computational biology. These workshops also provided discussion panels on biotechnology, sustainability, the graduate school application process as well as a summer research internship program hosted by our laboratories. Each summer one to three students visited the University of Georgia campus for an immersive research experience where they learned basic plant molecular genetics as well as basic computational biology.
